properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
• This Advice is being issued by South Gippsland Water for Inverloch.
  • People in Inverloch should not drink the tap water without boiling it first.
  • For more information visit www.sgwater.com.au or call 1300 851 636.
If you are in Inverloch then you must boil tap water before drinking it. 
What you should do:

  • Boil water before drinking it or drink bottled water.  
  • Boil water for food preparation, cleaning fruit and vegetables, making ice and for preparing baby formula. 
  • Boil water for brushing teeth.
To ensure water is safe to drink you should:

  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switched are suitable).
  • Allow water to cool before use.
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use.
  • Caution should be taken to prevent scalding from boiling water.
  • If you are concerned that you may have been affected by contaminated water please contact your doctor or call NURSE-ON-CALL 1300 60 60 24.

This message was issued by the Department of Health.

The next update is expected by 07/03/2022 or as the situation changes.


More information:

For health advice:
  • Call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24 - for expert health information and advice (24 hours, 7 days).

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Cann River

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT THE GORGE MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AT WEERAGUA AND CHANDLERS CREEK OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY 

Minor flooding is occurring along the Genoa River at the Gorge. Minor flooding is likely to develop along the Cann River at Weeragua and Chandlers Creek overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

In the 24 hours to 4 pm Tuesday, rainfall totals of 25-65 mm were recorded across the Bemm, Cann and Genoa River catchments. Rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are forecast for the remainder of Tuesday.

Bemm River:
Strong river level rises are occurring along the Bemm River.

Cann River:
Minor flooding is likely along the Cann River.The Cann River (West) at Weeragua is currently at 2.87 metres and steady. The Cann River (West) at Weeragua is likely to reach the minor flood level (3.00 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.The Cann River (East) at Chandlers Creek is currently at 1.80 metres and rising. 

The Cann River (East) at Chandlers Creek is likely to reach the minor flood level (2.00 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

Genoa River:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Genoa River.The Genoa River at The Gorge is currently at 2.21 metres and steady. The Genoa River at The Gorge is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.20 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. A minor flood peak is likely Wednesday morniing


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/03/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT MCKILLOPS BRIDGE 

Following recent rainfall, river levels are elevated in the Snowy River catchment with minor flooding occurring around McKillops Bridge and Basin Creek. Minor flooding is possible in the Bombala River at Bombala
overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

Elevated river levels are also expected along the Snowy River from Lake Jindabyne to McKillops Bridge in response to releases from Lake Jindabyne.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Tuesday rainfall totals of 5-20 mm were observed in the Snowy River catchment.
Rainfall totals of 20-30 mm are forecast for the rest of Tuesday.
 
Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is currently at 3.73 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River downstream of Basin Ck may fall below the minor flood level (3.50 m). Tuesday evening. Renewed minor flooding is likely from Wednesday morning.

The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 3.95 metres and steady. The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is likely to remain around the minor flood level (4.10 m) during Tuesday.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently at 4.07 metres and steady. The Snowy River at Orbost is likely to remain around the minor flood level (4.20 m) during Tuesday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/03/2022 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 

  • High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality.
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at Lake Bolac.

Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 

Agriculture information:
  •  Irrigation water contaminated with blue green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  •  Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue green algae.
Visitors to the area are advised that they can still enjoy other recreational activities such as bushwalking and sightseeing
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
If you see fish that are dead, dying or swimming erratically do not touch or eat them. 
This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 30/03/2022 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
  • For information on blue green algae and stock visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/pests-diseases-and-weeds/animal-diseases/beef-and-dairy-cows/blue-green-algal -poisoning-of-stock.
  • For information on blue green algae and irrigation visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/farm-management/soil-and-water/irrigation/blue-green-algae-and-irrigation-water.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Monday 28 February 2022, 02:56 pm
Next Update: Wednesday 30 March 2022, 03:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20252/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 

- High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality.
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 


Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River

MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AT ALL LOCATIONS ALONG THE SNOWY RIVER AND ALONG THE BUCHAN RIVER FROM OVERNIGHT TUESDAY INTO WEDNESDAY

Minor flooding occurring around McKillops Bridge and Basin Creek, with renewed rises expected during Wednesday. Minor flooding also likely at all other locations and along the Buchan River from overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

Elevated river levels are also expected along the Snowy River from Lake Jindabyne to McKillops Bridge in response to releases from Lake Jindabyne.

In the 24 hours to 5:00 pm Tuesday rainfall totals of 15-35 mm were observed in the Snowy River catchment.Rainfall totals of 5-15 mm are forecast for the remainder of Tuesday.

Bombala River:
Minor flooding may occur along the Bombala River.

The Bombala River at Bombala is currently at 2.37 metres and rising. The Bombala River at Bombala may reach the minor flood level (3.00 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is currently at 2.86 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge will remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. Renewed rises are expected during Wednesday.

Buchan River:
Minor flooding is likely along the Buchan River.The Buchan River at Buchan is currently at 2.16 metres and rising. The Buchan River at Buchan is likely to exceed the minor flood level (2.50 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. Additional rises are possible during Wednesday.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is currently at 3.62 metres and steady, with minor flooding. The Snowy River D/S Basin Ck is likely to remain around the minor flood level (3.50 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.Renewed rises are expected during Wednesday.

The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 3.81 metres and steady. The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is likely to remain around the minor flood level (4.10 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. Renewed rises are expected during Wednesday.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently at 3.98 metres and rising. The Snowy River at Orbost is likely to remain around the minor flood level (4.20 m) overnight Tuesday into Wednesday. Renewed rises are expected during Wednesday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 09/03/2022 05:50 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
